results.title: Milliya rumarra = Brand new day
results.creator_credit: David Noakes, Bryan McLellan, W A Filmworkers and I F Productions
results.brief_description: Aboriginal education is a part of life in aboriginal communities and survival of aboriginal culture and language is through the young. This documentary records the celebration of the first Aboriginal Arts in Perth 83 festival which attracted participants from all over Australia, including Maureen Watson, Jack Davis and Vic Hunter. Traditional dance, song and story-telling were a feature and interaction with the audience was encouraged - a way of sharing the Aboriginal culture with non-Aboriginal Australians. The film also documents Aboriginal community members from the Mowanjum Community in Derby, WA and the Warmun Community in Turkey Creek, WA, visiting schools in Perth, teaching the school-children about Aboriginal culture and traditions in an effort to improve race relations and bridge the gap of understanding between all Australians.

results.title: No problems
results.creator_credit: Jackie McKimmie, Queensland Film Development Office and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Mercy Steele remembers her childhood in Lowmead, Queensland in the 1920’s. Born on 10th March 1921, Mercy’s time with her mother was cut short when her mother died giving birth to her younger sister - her father eventually walked out on the family, leaving Mercy’s granny to look after the two girls. The film is a visual representation of Mercy’s childhood memories set in the lush landscape of Northern Queensland. This romantic view of a landscape mirrors the romantic view of what was in reality a harsh life. Storyteller and singer: Mercy Steele (Awards: Sydney Film Festival, 1990; St Kilda Film Festival, 1991)

results.title: New Norcia voices
results.creator_credit: A. Bruce Hodsdon and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: A companian piece to ‘New Norcia’ that contributes valuable background information this documentary combines interviews with a monk at the New Norcia monastery, historians, and aboriginal men and women who were brought-up at the mission. Each brings a different perspective to the legend of the founder Bishop Salvado, the legacy of the Mission and what this might mean today.

results.title: New Norcia. New Norcia voices
results.creator_credit: A. Bruce Hodsdon and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: A compilation of two companion films. ‘New Norcia’ (23 mins. 1990) is a representation through images and journal extracts of the history of contact between European and Aboriginal cultures, circa 1850-1900 at the Benedictine Mission at New Norcia in Western Australia. ‘New Norcia Voices’ (19 mins. 1992) combines interviews with a monk at the monastery, historians, and men and women who were brought-up at the mission. Each brings a different perspective to the legend of the founder Bishop Salvado, the legacy of the Mission and what this might mean today.’New Norcia’ narrated by Ian Taylor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: A. Bruce Hodsdon and Australian Film Commission

results.title: New Norcia
results.creator_credit: A. Bruce Hodsdon and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: This documentary explores the contact between European and Aboriginal cultures which occurred at the Benedictine community in New Norcia, Western Australia around 1850-1900. Extracts from the journal of the founder of the monastery Bishop Rosendo Salvado and photographs taken at New Norcia at the time are used to represent the history of the abbey and the contact between the cultures that occurred there.

results.title: Strike your heart
results.creator_credit: Wayne Barker, Nicki Lukacs and Strike Your Heart Productions
results.brief_description: Strike Your Heart is a gentle portrait of change; its happiness and heartbreak for a boy, a family and a culture. It is 1967 and Australian Aborigines have won the battle for their citizenship rights. New attitudes are being embraced by all and for a ten-year-old boy (Rami Rahman) living in the quiet coastal town of Broome, North-Western Australia, there are personal challenges that have to be faced - falling in love, his first kiss, heartbreak and departure from his close-knit Aboriginal family. Filmed on location in Broome, Western Australia - Wayne Barker’s homelands, with an indigenous cast from the region, “Strike Your Heart” is the first indigenous drama made in Western Australia. Cast includes Jimmy Edgar, Petris Torres, Attika Edgar, Alison Torres, Sylvia Clarke, Stephen ‘Baamba’Albert, Emmanuelle Torres, Brian T. Eastwell.

results.title: Dust to dust
results.brief_description: This documentary narrated by Kerry Dwyer reveals how the use by the local council of asbestos tailings from the mine at Baryulgil in New South Wales, which operated until 1977, has affected the health of the predominantly Aboriginal population. The dust was used to maintain roads and keep the earth dust down around the houses. The school itself was built on the tailings. The film records what happened historically at Baryugil and follows the people’s attempts to gain workers’ compensation from the Dust Diseases Board.

results.title: Goori goori dreaming
results.brief_description: Goori Goori Dreaming is a glimpse into the culture, traditions and spirit of Australia. Woven through the film are the contemporary paintings of Gunaminy Vanessa Fisher, as she teaches her family about the earth and their heritage.

results.title: Walking with my sisters
results.creator_credit: Bronwyn Kidd and Big Cat Productions
results.brief_description: Walking with my sisters is an engaging documentary about the struggle of three Aboriginal sisters to have their native title rights acknowledged and their land returned to them. The three Aboriginal sisters - Lorna Kelly, Linda Vidler and Yvonne Graham - are the traditional custodians of the Byron Bay area, and a main criterion they must meet in the claims process is to prove that they are in fact descendents of this land and not migrants from elsewhere. “Walking with my sisters” gives a broad outline of the various steps involved in making native title claims, such as the endless negotiations and the many interested parties and competing interests. Behind this complex process, however, lies the fact that Indigenous peoples were the original inhabitants of the land and that part of the ongoing process of reconciliation and defining Australia’s past and future involves grappling with this truth. Filmed over several years, “Walking with my sisters” shows a positive outcome to a long and deeply felt battle against what - at large - can be identified as cultural denial.

results.title: Cunnamulla
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke, ABC-TV (Australia), Camerawork and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The small outback town of Cunnamulla is situated in rural Queensland, 800 kilometres west of Brisbane. As one of the characters in this documentary says, “Cunnamulla is a town at the end of the railroad”, a once prosperous sheep farming territory that now has high levels of unemployment and petty crime. O’Rourke allows the people of the town to speak for themselves. The picture they paint is bleak; a town divided along racial and age lines, where whites and Aborigines are mutually suspicious of each other, where parents and grandparents can no longer understand the choices their children are making when it comes to sex, drugs and work. Filmed over the approaching Christmas period, “Cunnamulla” has its fair share of eccentric and stoic human beings, but the overriding impression is that the rapid pace of globalisation is exacerbating conflict and leading to the death of the very town itself. Whether it is in the doleful expression of a young man about to enter prison, or in the exasperated eyes of a father talking about his heavy metal obsessed son, O’Rourke’s film creates a vivid, powerful and disturbing portrait of outback Australia.
